button.title: Button: The Core of Interactivity
button.description: The button is a fundamental interactive element in web design. It's used to trigger actions like submitting forms, opening dialogs, confirming choices, or performing an operation. Unlike links, which are for navigation, buttons are for *actions*. Using the correct HTML element (`<button>`) provides essential accessibility and browser functionality for free, such as keyboard focus and form submission capabilities.
button.lesson:
Button Overview

Button provides a reusable pattern that is semantic, accessible, and adaptable to your design system. Use progressive enhancement: start with correct HTML, layer CSS for appearance, and add JavaScript only for behaviors that HTML alone cannot provide.

Accessibility Checklist:
- Use appropriate roles and ARIA attributes only when native semantics are insufficient.
- Ensure full keyboard support (Tab, Shift+Tab, Enter/Space, Arrow keys as relevant).
- Maintain sufficient color contrast and visible focus states.
- Announce dynamic changes with ARIA live regions where necessary.

Implementation Notes:
- Keep markup minimal and meaningful.
- Isolate styles behind component classes and CSS variables for easy theming.
- Avoid inline JavaScript. Prefer unobtrusive handlers loaded once per page.

Testing Tips:
- Navigate the component using only the keyboard.
- Test with a screen reader and high-contrast mode.
- Verify behavior without JavaScript to confirm graceful degradation.

modal.title: Modal: Focusing User Attention

avatar.title: Avatar: Representing Users
avatar.description: An avatar is a graphical representation of a user, typically a profile picture or initials. Avatars are commonly used in social applications, comment sections, and user menus to provide a personal touch and quick visual identification. They can be circular or square and often include a status indicator.
avatar.lesson: Avatar Overview Avatar provides a reusable pattern that is semantic, accessible, and adaptable to your design system. Use progressive enhancement: start with correct HTML, layer CSS for appearance, and add JavaScript only for behaviors that HTML alone cannot provide. Accessibility Checklist: - Use appropriate roles and ARIA attributes only when native semantics are insufficient. - Ensure full keyboard support (Tab, Shift+Tab, Enter/Space, Arrow keys as relevant). - Maintain sufficient color contrast and visible focus states. - Announce dynamic changes with ARIA live regions where necessary. Implementation Notes: - Keep markup minimal and meaningful. - Isolate styles behind component classes and CSS variables for easy theming. - Avoid inline JavaScript. progress_bar.description: Progress bars provide visual feedback on the status of a process, such as a download, upload, or multi-step form completion.
